awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Understanding and Automatically Adjusting Performance Sensitive Software Configurations
awd_abstract_narration:
Every day, people interact with complex software systems on their mobile devices and in the cloud.  Experts develop this software, but they cannot account for all possible uses, so they make the software configurable using redefinable parameters. Most of these parameters affect software's performance. These performance-related configuration parameters are growing exponentially.  Unfortunately, so is the difficulty of setting them.  Performance-related misconfigurations are a leading cause of system failures (e.g., web services crashing) and lag (e.g., delayed response to user requests).  This project will develop AutoConf to automatically set performance-related configuration parameters and eliminate these sources of failure in critical software infrastructure.

To better understand and manage performance-related configurations, AutoConf has four major research objectives.  The first is studying existing configuration parameters to understand why and when they lead to failures.  The second is designing a new interface where users set high-level goals in terms of desired performance rather than setting specific parameter values.  The third is developing techniques that automatically and dynamically configure software to meet these goals.  The final objective is constructing tools that ensure the interface's proper usage to produce the desired behavior.

If successful, AutoConf will change the way users deploy software.  Instead of setting 100s of configuration parameters, they will state their goals.  AutoConf will automatically adjust performance-related configurations to ensure the goals are met, resulting in faster and more robust software deployment. Additionally, the AutoConf project will create many research opportunities that will be used to broaden participation in computer science.

Documentation and software releases will be posted at http://autoconf.cs.uchicago.edu/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on configuration parameters that affect software performance, which we call PerfConfs for short.  These are parameters that software developers expose to users who are then responsible for setting those parameters to meet user-specific goals.  For example, a particular user might have a memory requirement for their software and that user would need to select the right parameter settings to ensure that---for their specific workload---the software’s memory is within the goal. These parameters can be very difficult to set because they require some knowledge of the software's internals yet they are often poorly documented.  Therefore, the project's overarching goal has been to build tools that help automate the understanding and configuration of these parameters.  

Overall, the project achieved significant intellectual breakthroughs in all four thrusts, resulting in numerous publications and releases of open-source software.  PI Hoffmann received a PECASE award, in part due to work supported by this project.  The project also produced multiple best paper awards. In addition, the project found a potential smart tv audio configuration that can leak sensitive data when users type on the virtual keyboard.  This issue was acknowledged by Samsung. Specifically, the project achieved the following outcomes for each of its key thrusts:

  • Finding new PerfConfs in cloud software, embedded systems, and IoT devices.
  • Developing tools to automatically identify potential PerfConfs in software systems without any user knowledge of the system internals.
  • Developing novel control techniques to automatically manage PerfConfs in running software.
  • Developing new machine learning methods for understanding PerfConfs, and critically, recognizing that when managing PerfConfs, better learning accuracy does not necessarily result in higher system performance.

In addition to the intellectual merits, this project created many opportunities for training students.  Eight different students who worked on some aspect of this project have completed a PhD, including multiple women and other students from historically under-represented backgrounds (5 total).  Furthermore, ideas from this project were incorporated into graduate classes on Power and Energy-aware computing.

Overall the work at the University of Chicago on understanding and managing PerfConfs created both significant intellectual output and meaningful experiences for students in research and in the classroom.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Henry Hoffmann
